Viral hepatitis is the seventh leading cause of mortality, exceeding that of HIV, tuberculosis and malaria.
1 Half of all viral hepatitis-related deaths are caused by hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection,
1 whose sequelae include hepatitis, fibrosis, cirrhosis and liver cancer.
1–3 HCV antibody (Ab) prevalence is estimated to be ∼1% for the global population,
4 in stark contrast to Egypt, which is estimated to have a prevalence of 10%
5–8 —possibly the highest prevalence worldwide.
